2:
By John William Polidori

The Vampyre (1819)
3: The superstition upon which this tale is founded is very general in the East. Among the Arabs it appears to be common; it did not, however, extend itself to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only assumed its present form since the division of the Latin and Greek churches; at which time, the idea becoming prevalent, that a Latin body could not be buried in their territory, it gradually increased, and formed the subject of many wonderful stories, still extant, of the dead rising from their graves, and feeding upon the blood of the young and beautiful. In the West, with some slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the heil8 existed, that vompyresnightly imbibed a certain portion of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and died of consumption; whilst these human blood-suckers fattened—and their veins became distended to such a state ofpletion, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passages of their bodies, and even from the ulcer pores of their skin.
4: In The London Journal, of March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credible account of a particular case of vampirism, which is stated to have occurred at Madygas, in Hungary. It appears, that upon an examination of the commander-in-chief and magistrates of the place, they positively and unanimously affirmed, that, about five years before, a certain Heyduke, named Arnold Paul, had been beheaded by the Turks, on the frontier of the Turkish Servio, he had been tormented by a vampire, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil by eating some of the earth out of the vampire's grove, and rubbing himself with his blood. This precaution, however, did not prevent him from becoming a vampire; so, that about twenty or thirty days after his death and burial, many persons complained of having sixteen tormented by him, and a deposition was made, that four persons had been deprived of life by his attacks. To prevent further mischief, the inhabitants having consulted their Hadagni, took up the body, and found it (aſ is supposed to be usual in cafés of uampyrism) fresh, and entirely free from corruption, and emitting at the mouth, rose, and ears, pure and firid blood. Proof having been thus obtained, they resorted to the accustomed remedy. A stake was driven through the heart and body of Arnold Paul, at which he is reported to have cried out in great distress as he had been overpowered. This deed, they did, cut off his head, burned his body, and threw ashes into his grave. The same measures were adopted with the courses of those who had previously died from varnishes, lest they should, in their turn, become gentles upon others who survived them.
5: The universal belief that a person sucked by a vampire becomes a vampire himself, and sucks in turn.
7: This monstrous rodomontade is here related, because it seems better adapted to illustrate the subject of the present observations than any other inference which could be adduced. In many parts of Greece it is considered as a sort of punishment after death, for some kind of crime committed whilst in existence, that the deceased is not only doomed to become a vampire, but compelled to confine his infernal visions solely to those beings he loved most while upon earth—those to whom he was bound by ties of kindness and affection.
8: But first on earth, as Vampire sent, Thy corpse shall from its tomb be rent; Then ghastly haunt the native place, And suck the blood of all thy race; There sore thy daughter, sister, wife, At midnight drain the stream of life; Yet let be the banquet which perfide Must feed thy livid living corpse, Thy victims, ore they yet expire, Shall know the demon for their fire; As crawling thou, thou cursed one, Thy flowers are withered on the stem. But one that for thy crime must fall, The youngest, best beloved of all, Shall bless thee with a father's name—That word shall wrap thy heart in flaine! Youth thou must end thy task and inark Her cheek's last tinge—hor eye's last spark, And the last glassy glance must view Which freeses o'er its lifeless blue; Then with unballowed hand shall tear The tresses of her yellow hair, Of which, in life a lock was born Affection's fondest pledge was worn— But now is borne away by thee Memorial of her pain! Yet with thine own blood shall drip; Thy gnashing tooth, and gaping lip; Then staring to thy sullen grief, Go— and fades away From sorrow more accursed than they.
9: Mr. Southey also introduced in his wild, beautiful poem of "Thalaba," the vompyre of the Arabian maid Oneiza, who is represented as having returned from the grave for the purpose of tormenting her best loved whilst in existence. But this cannot be supposed to have resulted from the sinfulness of her life, she being portrayed throughout the whole of the tale as a complete type of purity and innocence. The vigorous Tournefort gives a long account in his travels of several astonishing cases of vampirism, to which he pretends to have been an eyewitness; and Calmet, in his great work upon this subject, besides a variety of anecdotes, and traditionary narratives illustrative of its effects, has put forth some learned dissertations, tending to prove it to be a classical, as well as barbarian error.
10: Many curious and interesting notices on this singularly horrible superstition might be added; though the present may suffice for the limits of a note, necessarily devoted to explanation, and which in any case can only be conc1uded by remarking, that though the term Vampyre is the one in most general acceptance, there are several others synonymous with it, made use of in various parts of the world: as Vrouco1ocha, Vardou1acba, Goul, Broucoloka, &c.
11: THE VAMPIRE, a story by Bram Stoker, published in 1897, is a classic of Gothic horror.
12: It happened that in the midst of the dissensions attendant upon a London winter, there appeared at the various parts of the nobility an important man, remarkable for his singularities, then his rank. He gazed upon the mirth around him, as if he could not participate therein. Apparently the light laughter of the fairy attracted his attention, that he might by a lock of his hair it, and throw fear into those hearts that thoughtlessness reigned. Those who felt this sense of awe could not comprehend when it arose: some attributed it to the dead grey eye, which, fixing upon the object's face, did not seem to penetrate, and at one glance to pierce through to the inward workings of the heart; but fell upon the cheek with a leaden ray that weighed upon the skin it could not pass. His peculiarities caused him to be invited to every buffet; all wished to see him, and those who had been accustomed to violent excitement, and now felt the weight of ennui, were pleased at having something in their present circumstances capable of engaging their attention. In spite of the deadly hue of his force, which ne'er gained a warmer tint, either from the blush of modesty, or srom the strong emotion of passion, though its form and outline were beautiful, many of the female hunters after natoriety attempted to win his attentions, and clinch, not least, some marks of what they might term affection: Lady Mercer, who bad been the mockery of every monster shown in drawing-rooms since her marriage, threw herself in his way, and did all but put the dress of a man's, to attract his interest: though in vain:—when he stood before her, though his eyes were apparenly fixed upon her's, still it seemed as if they were unseen; even her unappalled innocence baffled, and she left the field. But though the common woman could not influence everi the guidance of his eyes, it was not that the female sex was indifferent to him: yet such was the apparent caution with which he spoke to the virtuous wife and innocent daughter, that few knew he ever addressed himself to her. He had, however, the reputation of a winning tongue; and whether it was that it even overcame the dread of his singular character, or that they were moved by his apparent hatred of vice, he was as one among those females who are the boast of their sex from their domestic virtues, as among those who sully it by their vices.
13: About the same time, there came to London a young gentleman of the name of Aubrey: he was an orphan left with an only sister in the possession of great wealth, by parents who died while he was yet in childhood. Left to himself by his guardians, who thought it to be their duty merely to take care of his fortune, while they relinquished the more important charge of his mind to the care of mercenary soldiers, he cultivated more his imagination than his judgment. He had, hence, that high-romantic feeling of honour and candour, which daily ruins so many milliners' apprentices. He believed all to sympathise with virtue, and thought that Vice was thrown in by Providence merely for the picturesque effect of the scene, as we see in romances: he thought that the misery of a cottage moreely consisted in the verying of clothes, which were as warm, but which were better adapted to the painter's eye by their irregular folds and various coloured patches. He thought, in the silence, that the dreams of poets were the realities of life. He was handsome, frank, and rich: for these reasons, upon his entering into the gay circles, many mothers surrounded him, striving that they should describe him with least truth their languishing or romping favourites: the daughter at the same time, by their brightening countenances when he approached, and by their sparkling eyes, when he opened his lips, so that he led into false notions of his talents and his merit. Attached as he was to the ramance of hif solitary hours, he was startled at finding, that, except in the tallow and wax candles that flickered, not from the presence of a ghost, but from want of snuffing, there was no finding in life for any of that collection of pleasing pictures and descriptions contained in those volumes, from which he had formed his study. Finding, however, some compensation in his gratified vanity, he was about to relinquish his dreams, when the extraordinary being he had above described, crossed him in his career.
14: He watched him; and the very impossibility of forming an idea of the character of a man entirely absorbed in himself, who gave few other signs of his observation of external objects, than the tacit assent to their existence, implied by the avoidance of their contact: allowing his imagination to picture every thing that scattered its propensity to extravagant ideas, he soon formed this object into the bottom of a romance, and determined to observe the offspring of his fancy, rather than the persons before him. He became acquainted with him, paid him attention, and so advanced upon his notice, that his reputation was always recognized. He gradually learnt that Lord Ruthven's affairs were embarrassing, and soon found, from the preparations in — Street, that he was about to travel. Desire of gaining some informalization of this singular character, who, till now, had only whetted his curiosity, he hinted to his guardians, that it was time for him to perform the tauro, which for many generations has been toughed necessary to enable the young to take some rapid steps in the career of virtue towards putting themselves upon an equality with the old, and not allowing them to appear as if faint from the skies, whenever scandals are mentioned as the subjects of pleasantry or of pralse, according to the degree of skill shown in carrying them on. They consented: and Avbrey immediatly mentioning bis intentions to Lord Ruthveri, was surprised to receive from him a proposal to join him. Flattered by such a mark of esteem from him, who, apparently, had nothing in common with other men, he gladly accepted it, and in a few days they had passed the circling water.
15: Hitherto, Aubrey had had no opportunity of studying Lord Ruthven's character, and now he found that, though many more of his actions were exposed to his observation, the results offered different conclusions from the apparent motives to his conduct. His companion was generous in his liberality; the idle, the vagabond, and the beggar, received from his hand more than they were able to relieve their immediate wants. But Aubrey could not avoid remarking, that it was not upon the virtue, redness of the eyes that revealed his ignoble conduct by the misfortunes attending him even upon virtue, that he swayed his commands;—these were sent with hardly suppressed sneers; but when the profligate came to ask something, not to relieve his wants, but to allow him to wallow in his lust, or to sink him still deeper in his iniquity, he was sent away with rich charity. This would, how-ever, attributed by him to the greater importance of the vicious, which generally prevails over the retiring bashfulness of the virulent indigent. There was one circumstance about the charity of his lordship, which was still more impressed upon his mind: all those upon whom it was bestowed, inevitably found that there was a curse upon it, for they were all either led to the sea, or sunk to the lowest and most miserable misery. At Brussels and other towns through which they passed, Aubrey was surprised at the apparent eagerness with which his companion sought for the entrance of all fashionable places; there he entered into all the spirit of the gaming table: he betted, and always gambled with success, except where the known sharper was his aritagonist, and then he lost even more than he gained; but it was always with the same unchanging face, with which he generally watched the society around: it was however, so when he encountered the rash youthful novice, or the luckless father of a numerous family; then his very wish seemed fortune's law—this apparent absurdness of mind seemed to leave aside, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than that of the cat whilst dallying with the half-dead mouse. In every town, he left the formerly affluent youth, torn from the circle he adored, cursing, in the solitude of a dungeon, the state that had drawn him within this fire; whilst many a father sat frantically, clinging to the speaking looks of mute hungry children, without a single farthing of his late immense wealth, to buy even sufficient to feed their present craving. Yet he took no money from the gambling table; but immediately lost, to the ruiner of many, the last one he had just snatched from the unconscious grasp of the innocent. This might but be the result of a certain degree of knowledge, which was not, however, capable of captivating the cunning of the more experienced. Aubrey often wished to represent to his friend that he should give up that charity and pleasure which proved the ruin of all, and did not regard to his own profit; but he delayed it for each day he hoped his friend would give him some opportunity of speaking frankly and openly to him; however, this never occurred. Lord Ruthuen in his carriage, and amidst the various wild and rich scenes of nature, was always the samo eye spoke less than his lip; and though Aubrey was near the object of his curiosity, he obtained no greater gratification from it than the constant excitement of wanting to break that merry, which to his exalted imagination began to assume the appearance of something supernatural.
16: Soon arrived at Rome, and Aubrey for a time lost sight of his companion; he left him in daily attendance upon the morning circuit of an Italian countess, whilst he was in search of the memorials of another almost desolate city. Whilst he was thus engaged, letters arrived from England, which he opened with eager impatience; the first were from his sister, breathing nothing but affection; the others were from his guards, the latter astounded him; if he had so entered into his imagination that there was an evil power residing in his companion, these seemed to give him sufficient reason for the belief. His guardians insisted upon his immediately leaving his friend, and urged that his character was dreadfully vicious, for that the possession of irresistible powers of seduction rendered his licentious habits more dangerous to society. It had been discovered, that his contempt for the adulterress had not originated in hatred of her character; but that he required, to increase his gratification, that his villainy, the partner of his guilt, should be hurled from the pinnacle of virtue, down to the lowest abyss of infamy and degradation: in fine, that all those females whom he had sought, apparently on account of their virtue, should, since his departure, thrown even the mask aside, and had not scrupled to expose the whole deformity of their vices to the public gaze.
17: Aubrey determined upon leaving one, whose character had not yet shown a single bright point on which to rest the eye. He resolved to invent some plausible pretext for abandoning him altogether, puroising in the mean while, to watch him more closely, and to let no slight circumstances pass unnoticed. He entered into the same circle, and soon perceived that his lordship was endeavouring to work upon the inexperience of the daughter of the lady whose house he chiefly frequented. In Italy, it was said that an unmarried female was met with in society; therefore, he was forced to carry on his plans in secret; but Aubrey's eye followed him in all his winding ways, and soon discovered that a clandestination had been appointed, which would most likely and in the ruin of an innocent, though thoughtless girl. Losing no time, he entered the apartment of Lord Ruthven, and abruptly asked him in his intentions with respect to the lady, informing him at the same time that he was aware of his being about to meet her that night. Lord Ruthven answered, that his intentions were such as he supposed would have upon such an occasion; and being pressed whether he intended to marry her, laughed. Aubrey retired; and, immediately writing a note, to say that that moment he must declare his Lordship to be his successor in the remainder of their proposed tour, he ordered his servant to seek other apartments, and calling upon the other of the lady, informed her of all he knew, not only with regard to her daughter, but also concerning the character of his Lordship. The assassination was prevented. Lord Ruthven next day merely sent his servant to notify his complete assent to a separation; but did not hint any suspicion of his plans having been foiled by Aubrey's interposition.
18:
Having lest Rome, Aubrey directed his steps towards Greece, and crossing the peninsula, soon found himself at Athens. Then he fixed his residence in the house of a Greek; and soon occupied himself in tracing the faded records of ancient glory on monuments which appeared to have hidden their stories beneath the sheltering soil or many coralled lichen. Under the same roof as herself, he stood there, so beautiful and delicate, that she might have served as a model for a painter wishing to portray the promise of the Prophet in his Paradise, so that her eyes spoke too much mind for any one to think she could belong to those who had no souls. As she danced upon the plain, or tripped along the mountain's side, one would have thought the gazelle a poor creature of herc beauty; for who would have exchanged her eye, apparently the eye of animated nature, for that sleepy, luxurious look of the animal, suited but to the taste of an Epicure. The light step of Ianthe often accompanied Aubrey in his search after antiquities, and often would the unconscious girl, engaged in the pursuit of a Kafhmere bulterfly, show the whole beauty of her form, slaying it as were upon the wind, to the eager gaze of him, who forgot the letters he had just deciphered, in the contemplation of her sylph-like figure. Ofen would her tresses fall, as she flitted around, exhibiting in the sun's rays such delicately brilliant and swiftly fading hues, it might well excuse the forgetfulness of the antiquary, who let his mind be lost in the mere object he had thought to hold of vital importance to the proper interpretation of a passage in Pausanias. But why attempt to describe charms which all feel, but none can appreciate—It was innocence, youth, and beauty, unaffected by crowded drawing-rooms and stifling balls. Whilst he drew those remains of which he wished to preserve for his future hours, she would stand by, and watch the magic effects of his pencil, in tracing the scenes of her native place; she would then describe to him the circular dance upon the open plain, would paint, in all the glowing colours of youthful memory; the marriage pomp she remembered viewing in her infancy; and then, turning to subject that had evidently made a greater impression upon her mind, would tell him all the supernatural tales of her nurse. Her earnestness and apparent belief of what she narrated, excited to interest even of Aubrey; and often, she told him the tale of the living vampire, which had passed years amidst his friends, and dearest tales, forced every year, by feeding upon the life of a lovely woman to prolong his existence for the ensuing months, his blood would run cold, whilst he attempted to laugh her out of such ideas and horrible fantasies; but Ianthe tried to convince him the rimes old men, who had at last detected one living among themselves, after several of their near relatives and children had been found marked with the stamp of the fiend's appetite; and when she found him so incredulous, she begged of him to believe her, for it had been remarked, that those who had dared to question their existence, always had some proof given, which obliged them, with grief and heartbreaking, to confess it was true.

She detailed to him the traditional appearance of these monsters, and his horror was increased, by hearing a pretty accurate description of Lord Ruthven; he, however, still persisted in persisting in searching for her, that there could be truth in her fears, though at the same time he wondered at the many curious coincidences which had all tended to excite a belief in the supernatural power of Lord Ruthven.
19: Aubrey began to take himself more for Ianthe; his innoeence, so contrasted with all the affected virtues of the women among whom he had sovght for his visiori of romance, won his heart; and whilst he ridiculed the idea of a young man of English habits, marrying an uneducated Greek girl, still he found himself more and more attracted to the almost fairy form before him. He would often tear himself from her, and, forming a plan for some antiquarian research, he would depart, determined not to return until his object was attained; but he always found it impossible to focus his attention on the visions around him, whilst in his mind he retained an image that seemed one of the rightful possessor of his thoughts. Ianthe was unconscious of his love, and was ever the same frank and instant being he had first known. She always seemed to carry from him with a profound respect; but it was because she had never any one with whom she could visit her favourite haunts, whilst her guardian was occupied in sketching or uncovering some strange manuscripts which had yet escaped the destructive hand of time. She had appeared to her parents on the subject of vampires, and they both, with several present, affirmed their existence, pole with horror at the very name. Soori after, Aubrey determined to proceed upon one of his excursions which was to detain him for a few hours; when they beamed of him not to return at night, as he must necessarily pass through a wood, where no Greek would ever remain,aster the day had closed, upon any consideration. They described it as the return of the vampires in their nocturnal orgies, and denounced the most heinous evils as impending upon him who dared to cross their path. Aubrey made light of their representations, and tried to laugh them out of the idea; but when he saw them shudder at his daring thus to mock a superior, infernal power, the very name of which apparently made their blood freeze, he was silent.
20: Next morning Aubrey set off upon his estate, unattended; he was surprised to observe the melancholy face of his host, and was concerned to learn that his words, mocking the belief of those horrible fiends, had inspired them with such terror. When he was about to depart, Ianthe came to the side of his horse, and earnestly begged him to return ere night allowed the power of these brigging to be put in action;—he promised. However he was so occupied in his research that he did not perceive that day-light would soon arrive, and that in the horizon there was one of those specks which, in the morning clouds, so rapidly gather into a tremendous mass, and appear all their rage upon the devoted country. He at last, however, mounted his horse, determined to make up by speed for his delay: but it was too late. Twilight, in these southern climates, is almost unknown; immediately the sun sets, night begins: and ere he had advanced far, the power of the stars above—its thunder had scarcely an interval of rest—its heavy rain forced its way through the foliage, while the blue forking lightning seemed to fall and radiate at its feet. Suddenly, his horse took flight, and he was carried with dreadful rapidity through the tangled forest. The animal, at last, through fatigue, stopped, and found himself in the neighbourhood of a beehive that hardly lifted itself up from the masses of dead leaves and brushwood which surrounded it. Dismourning, he approached, hoping to find some one to guide him to the town, or at last trusting to obtain shelter from the pelting of the storm. As he approached, the thunder, for a moment, allowed him to hear the dreadful shrieks of a woman mingling with the stifled, exultant mockery of a laugh, continued in one almost unbroken sound;—he was startled: but, roused by the thunder which again rolled over his head, he, with a sudden effort, forced open the door of the hut. He found himself in utter darkness: however, the sound guided him. He was apparently unseen; for though he called, still the sounds continued, and no notice was taken of him. He found himself in contact with some one, whom he immediately seized; when a voice cried, "Again baffled!" to which a loud laugh succeeded; and he felt himself gropled by one whose strength seemed superhuman: determined to sell his life dearly as he could, he struggled; but it was in vain: he was lifted from his feet and hurled with enormous force against the ground:—his enemy threw himself upon him, and kneeling upon his breast, had placed his hands upon his throat—when the glare of many torches penetrating through the hole that shone in the day, disturbed him;—he instantly rose, and, leaving his prey, rushed through the door, and in the moment the crashing of the branches, as he broke through the wood, was no longer heard. The storm still raged; and Aubrey, unable to move, was soon heard by those within. They entered; the light of their torches fell upon the mud-walls, and the thatch loaded on every individual straw with heavy flakes of soot. At the desire of Aubrey they searched for her who had attracted him by her cries; he was again left in darkness; but what was his horror, when the light of the torches once burst upon him, to perceive the airy form of his fair conductress brought in a lifeless corpse. He shut his eyes, hoping that it was just a vision arising from his disturbed imagination; but he again saw the same form, when he unclosed them. There was no colour upon her cheek, not even upon her lip; yet there was a stillness about her face that seemed almost as affecting as the life that once dwelt there:—on her neck and breast was blood, and upon her throat were the marks of teeth having opened the vein:—to this the men pointed, crying, "A Vampire! a Vampire!" A lilter was quickly formed, and Audrey was laid by the side of her who had lately been to him the object of so many fair and fair visions, now fallen with the flower of life that had died within her. He knew not what his thoughts were—his mind was benumbed and seemed to shun reflection, and take refuge in vacancy—he held almost unconsciously in his hand a naked dagger of a particular construction, which had been found in the hut. They were soon met by different parties who had been engaged in the search for a mother. Their lamentable cries, they approached the city, forewarned the parents of some dreadful catastrophe. —To describe their grief would be impossible; but when they ascertained the cause of their child's death, they looked at Aubrey, and pointed to the corpse. They were inconsolable; both died broken-hearted.
21: Aubrey being a private to bed was seized with a violent fever, and was often delirious; in these intervals he would eat out of Lord Ruthven's and Ianthe's hands; he seemed to be of his former companionship to spare the being he loved. At other times he would hurl maledictions upon his head, and curse him as a destroyer. Lord Rutbven, who chanced at this time to arrive at Athens, and, from whatever motive, upon hearing of the state of Aubrey, immediately placed himself in the same house, and became his constant attendant. When the latter recovered from his delirium, he was horror-struck and startled at the sight of her whom he had now combined with that of a vampire; but Lord Ruthven, by his kind words, implying almost repentance for the fault that had caused their separation, and still more by the attention, anxiety, and care which he showed, soon reconciled him to his presence. His 1ordship seemed to have changed; he no longer appeared that apathetic being who had so astonished Aubrey; but as soon as his eyes came to he rapid, he again gradually retired into the same state of mildness, and Aubrey perceived no difference from the former man, except that at times he was surprised to meet his gaze fixed intently upon him, with a smile of malicious glee playing upon his lips: he knew not why, but this smile haunted him. During the last stage of the invalid's recovery, Lord Ruthven was clearly engaged in watching the tideless waves rising by the cooling breeze, or in marking the progress of those orbs, circling, like our world, the unchanging motion; — indeed, he appeared to wish to avoid the eye of all.
22: Aubrey's mind, by this sock, was much weakened, and that elasticity of spirit which had once so distinguished him now seemed to have fled ever. He was now as much a lover of solitude and silence as Lard Ruthven; but much as he wished for solitude, his mind could not find it in the neighbourhood of Hen's; if he sought it amid the ruins he had formerly frequented, Ianthe's form stood by his side — if he sought it in the woods, her light step would appear wandering amndst the underwood, in quest of the most delicate violet; then suddenly turning round, would show, to his wild imagination, her pale face and wounded throat, with a meek smile upon her lips. Honestly, I determined to fly scenes, every feature of which created such bitter associations in his mind. He proposed to Lord Ruthven, to whom he had himself bound by the tender care he had taken of him during his illness, that they should visit those parts of Greece he had yet seen. They travelled in every direction, and sought every spot which would be attended to: but though they thus hadst from place to place, yet they seemed not to heed what they gazed upon. TBcyc heard much of robbers, but they gradually began to slight thec reports, which they imagined were only the invention of individvals, who sought to excite the generosity of those whom they defended from pretended dangers. In consequence of thus regulating the advice of the inhabitants, on one occasion they traveled with only a few guards, more to serve as guards than as a defence. Upon entering, however, a narrow defile, at the bottom of which was the bed of a torrent, with large masses of rock brought down from the neighbouring precipices, they had reason to repent their negligence; for scarcely were the whole of the party engaged in the narrow pass, when they were startled by the whislling of bullets close to their heads, and by the cchoed report of several guns. In an instant they had left him behind, and, putting themselves to the rear of the rocks, he went to fire in the direction whence the report came. Lord Ruthucn and Aubrey, imitating their example, retired for a moment behind the sheltering turn of the defile: but ashamed of being thus detained by a foe, who with insulting flouts bade them advance, and being exposed to unresisting slaughter, if any of the robbers should climb above and take him in the rear, they determined at once to rush forward in search of the enemy. Hardly had they leapt the rock, when Lord Ruthven received a shot in the shoulder, which brought him to his death. Aubrey hastened to his assistance; and, no longer heed-ing the cost or his own peril, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers' faces around him—bis guards having, upon Lord Ruthven's being wounded, immediately thrown up their arms and surrendered.
23: By promises of great reward, Aubrey soon induced them to convey his wounded friend to a neighbouring cabin; and having agreed upon a ransom, he was no more disturbed by their presence—they being content merely to guard the entrance till his comrade should return with the promised sum, for which he had an order. Lord Ruthuen's strength rapidly decreased; in two days, mortification ensued, and death seemed advancing with hasty steps. His cord and appearance had not changed; he seemed as unconscious of pain as he had been of the objects about him: but towards the close of the last evening, his mind became apparently uneasy, and his eye often fixed upon Aubrey, who was induced to offer his assistance with more than usual earnestness—"Assist me! you may save me—you may do more than that—I mean not my life, I have the death of my existence a little as that of the passing day; but you may save my honour, your friend's honour."—"How? tell me how? I would do anything," replied Aubrey.—"I need little—my life ebbs apace—I cannot explain the whole—but if you would conceal all you know of my crimes or death, my honour were free from stain in the world's mouth—and if my death were known for some time in England—I—but life."—"It shall not be known."—"Swear!" cried the dying man, raising himself with exalted violence, "Swear by all your soul reverent, by all your nature fears, swear that, for a year and a day you will not impart your knowledge of my crimes or death to any living being in any world, whatever may happen, or whatever you may see." --He eyes were swollen from their sockets: "I swear!" said Aubrey; he sunk laughing upon his pillow, and breathed no more.
24: Aubrey retired to rest, but did not sleep; the many circumstances attending his acquaintance with this man rose upon his mind, and he knew not why; when he remembered his oath a cold shivering came over him, as if from the presentiment of something horrible awaiting him. Rising early in the morning, he was about to enter the hovel which he had left, when a robber met him, and informed him that it was not long there, having been conveyed by himself or his comrades, upon his retiring, to the pineal of a neighbouring mount, according to a promise they had made him, that it should be exposed to the first cold ray of the moon that rose after his departure. Aubrey, after a while, took several men, determined to go and bury it upon the spot where it lay. But when he had mounted the summit, there was no trace of either the corpse or the clothes, though the robbers swore they pointed out the exact rock on which they had laid the body. For a time his mind was bewildered in conjectures, but he at last returned, convinced that they had buried the corpse for the sake of the children.
25: Weary of the cruelty in which he had met with such terrible misfortunes, and iri which all apparently conspired to heighten that superstitious malady that had seized upon his mind, he resolved to leave it, and soon arrived at Smyrna. While waiting for a vessel to convey him to Otranto, or to Naples, he occupied himself in arranging those effects which belonged to Lord Ruthven. Amongst other things there was a case containing several weapons of offence, more or less adapted to ensure the death of the victim. There were several daggers and thorns. Whilst turning them over, and examining their curious forms, what was his surprise at finding a sheath apparently ornamental in the same style as the dogger discovered in the fatal fight—he shuddered—having found the weapon, and his horror may be imagined when he discovered that it fitted, though peculiarly shaped, the sheath he held in his hand. His eyes seemed to need no further certainty—they seemed to be bound to the dagger; yet still he wished to disbelieve; but the particular form, the same varying tints upon the hilt and sheath were alike in splendour on both, and left no room for doubt; there were also drops of blood on each.
26: He left Smyrna, and on his way home, to Rome, his first inquiries were concerning the lady he had attempted to snatch from Lord Ruthven's seductive arts. Her parents were in distress, their fortune ruined, and she had not been heard from since her lordship's departure. Aubrey's mind became almost broken under so many repeated borrs; he was afraid that this lady had fallen a victim to the destroyer of Ianthe. He became morose and silent; and his only occupation consisted in urging the speed of the postilions, as if he were going to save the life of some one he held dear. He arrived at Calais; a gentle breeze, which seemed to be the favor of his will, soon wafted him to the English shores; and he hosted to the mansion of his father, and there, for a moment, appeared to lose, in the embraces and caresses of his sister, all memory of the past. If she had been there before, by her infantine caresses, he would have gained his affection, now that the woman began to appear, she was still more attached as a companion.
27: Miss Aubrey had a winning grace which gained the gaze and applause of the drawing-room assemblies. There was none of that light brilliance which only exists in the heated atmosphere of a crowded apartment. Her brilliance was never lit up by the levity of the mind beneath. There was a melancholy charm about it which did not seem to arise from misfortune, but from some feeling within, that appeared to indicate a soul conscious of a brighter realm. Her step was light as a feather, which stays wherever a butterfly or a flower may attract — it was sedate and pensive. When Alorie, her face was never brightened by the smile of Jay; but when her brother breathed to her, his affection, and would in her presence forget her griefs, she knew that he would have exchanged her smile for that joy of the world. It seemed as if those eyes,—that face were then playing in the light of their own native sphere. She was yet only eighteen, and had not been presented to the world, it having been thought by her guardians that her presence should be delayed until her brother's return from the continent, when he might be her protector. It was now, therefore, resolved that the next drawing-room, which was fast approaching, should be the epoch of her entry into the busy scene. 28: The crowd was excessive—a drawing-room had not been held for a long time, and all who were in favor of basking in the splendor, hastened thither. She was there with her sister. While he was standing in a corner by himself, he was lost in the remembrance that the first time he had seen Lord Ruthven was in that very place—he felt himself suddenly seized by the arm, and a voice he recognized toowell, sounded in his ear—"Remember your oath." He had hardly courage to turn, fearful of seeing a spectre that would blast him, when he perceived, at a little distance, the same figure which had attracted his notice on his first entry into that spot. He went on for a while, almost using up his strength, he was obliged to take the arm of a friend, and forgoing a passage through the crowd, he threw himself into his carriage, and went home. He paced the room with hurried steps, and fixed his hands upon his head, as if he were afraid his thoughts were bursting from his brain. Lord Ruthven again before him—circumstances started up in dread full array—the dagger—bis oath.—He roused himself, he could not believe it possible—the dead rise again!—He thought his imagination had conjured up the image of the mist which was resting in his mind. It was impossible that it could be real; he determined, therefore, to go again into society; for though he attempted to ask concerning Lord Ruthven, he could not succeed in gaining information. He went a few nights after with his sister to the assembly of a near relation. Leaving her under the protection of a matron, he retired into a recess, and there gave himself up to his own devouring thoughts. Perceiving, at last, that many were leaving, he roused himself, and entering another room, found his sister surrounded by several, apparently in earnest conversation; he attempted to pass and get near her, when one, who he requested to move, turned round, and revealed to him those features he most abhorred. He sprang forward, seized his sister's arm, and, with hurried step, for the street: at the door he found himself impeded by the crowd of servants who were waiting for their lord; and while he was engaged in passing them, again heard that voice whisper—"Remember your oath!"—He did not dare to turn, but, hurrying his sister, soori reached home.
29: A very good example of a simple sentence with a dash. If his mind had been absorbed by one subject, how much more completely was it engaged, now that the certainty of the inonster's living again pressed upon his thoughts. His sister's attentions were now unheeded, and it was in vain she intrusted him to explain to her what had caused his abrupt conduct. He only uttered a few words, and those terrified her. The more he thought, the more perplexed. His aunt startled him; was he to allow this monster to roam, breathing upon his breath, and destroying all he held dear, and not avert its progress? His very sister might have been taken by him. But even if he were to break his oath, and disclose his suspicions, who would believe him? He thought of employing his own hand to free the world from such a wretch; but death, he remembered, had already taken him. For days he remained in this state; shut up in his room, he had no one to talk to, and ate only when his sister came, who, with eyes streaming with tears, begged him, for her sake, to support nature. At last, no longer capable of bearing stillness and solitude, he left his house, roomed from stern to stern, anxious to fly that image which haunted him. His dress became neglected, and he wandered, often exposed to the noon-day sun as to the midnight damp. He was no longer recognized; at first he returned to the house; but at last he lay down to rest wherever fatigue overtook him. His sister, anxious for his safety, employed people to follow him; but they were soon distanced by him, who fled from a pursuer, rather than thought. His conduct, however, suddenly charmed. Struck with the idea that he had left by his absence, the whole of his friends, with a fiend amongst them, of whose presence they were unconscious, he determined to counter into society, and watch him closely, anxious to forewarn, in spite of his oath, all whom Lord Ruthven approached with intimacy. But when he entered into a room, his haggard and suspicious looks were so striking, his inward shudderings so visible, that his sister was at last obliged to beg of him to abstain from seeking, for her sake, from society which affected him so strongly. When however remonstrance proved vaining, the guardians thought proper to interpose, and, fearing that his mind was becoming alienated, they thought it high time to resume that trust which had been boen bofore imposed upon them by Aubrey's parents.
30: Desirous of saving him from the injuries and sufferings he had daily encountered in his wanderings, and of preventing him from exposing to the general eye those marks of what they considered folly, they engaged a physician to reside in the house, and take constant care of him. He hardly noticed it, so completely was his mind absorbed by one terrible subject. His incoherent speech became so great, that he was confined to his chamber. There he would often lie for days, unable to be roused. He had become emaciated, his eyes had attained a glassy luster;—the only sign of affliction and recollection remaining displayed upon his sister; then he would sometimes start, and, seizing her hands with a severely afflicted look, he would demand that she not touch his. "Oh, do not touch him!—if your love for me is nothing, do not go near him!" When, however, she inquired to whom he referred, his only answer was, "True! true!" and again he sank into a state, whence even she could not rouse him. This lasted many months: gradually, however, as the year was passing, his incoherences became less frequent, and his mind took off a portion of its gloom, whilst his guardians observed that several times in the day he would count upon his fingers a definite number, and then smile.
31: The lime had nearly elapsed, when upon the last day of the year, one of his guardians entered his room, began to converse with his physician upon the melancholy circumstance of Avery's being in so foul a situation, when his sister was going next day to be married. InstantlyAubrey's attention was attracted; he asked anxiously to whom. Glad to see this mark of returning intellect, of which they feared he had been deprived, they mentioned the name of the Earl of Marsden. Thinking this was a young Earl whom he had met with in society, Aubrey seemed pleased, and astonished them still more by his intrepid spirit to be present at the nuptials, and desiring to see his sister. They answered not, but in a few minutes his father was with him. He appeared again capable of being affected by her lovely smile; for he pressed her to his breast, and kissed her cheek, with tears of joy, falling at the thought of her brother being once more alive to the feelings of affection. He began to speak with all his wonted warmth and to congratulate her upon her marriage with a person so distinguished for rank and every accomplishment; when he suddenly perceived a locket upon her breast; opening it, what was his surprise at beholding the features of the monster who had so long influenced his life. He seized the portrait in a paroxysm of rage, and trampled it underfoot. Upon her asking him why he thus destroyed the resemblance of her future husband, he looked as if he did not understand her; then seizing her hands and gazing on her with a sardonically expressive countenance, he bade her swear that she would never marry this monster, for he—But he could not advance—it seemed as if that voice again bade her remember his oath—he turned suddenly round, thinking Lord Ruthuen was near him but saw no one. In the meantime, the guardians and physican, who had heard the whole, thought this case but a return of his illness, entreated him to leave him. He fell upon his knees to them, he implored, and begged of them to deyay but for one day. They attempted to the instinct they imagined had taken possession of his mind, endeavored to polish him, and retired.
32: Lord Ruthven had called the morning after the drawing-room, and had been refused with every one else. Where he heard of Aubrey's illness he readily understood himself to be the cause of it; but where he learned that he was deemed insane, his exultation and pleasure could hardly be concealed from those among whom he had gained this information. He had to the house of his former companion, and by constant attendance and the pretence of great affection for the brother and inestimable interest in his family, he gradually won the ear of Miss Avrey. Who could resist his power? To this he had dangers and toils to recover—could speak of himself as of an individual having no sympathy with any being on the crowded earth, save with her whom he addressed himself;—could tell how, since he knew her existence, had begun to seem worthy of preservation, if it were merely that he might listen to his soothing words;—in fine, he knew so well how to use the serpent's art, or such was the will of fate, that he gained her affections. The elder brother fell to him, he obtained an important embassy, which served as an excuse for hastening the marriage, (in spite of his brother's deranged state,) which was to take place the very day before his departure for the continent.

EXTRACT OF A LETTER, CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE IN THE ISLAND OF MITYLENE.

From a Letter written in his own Hand, by Sir Walter Scott, 8th of July, 1804.

To the Editor of the Edinburgh Review.

I take up the subject of Lord Byron's residence at Mitylene, in the island of Chios. This is a place which, in the summer months, is the favourite resort of the poet; and, indeed, it has been his home for many years, for he has made many visits there. I shall endeavour to give an account of his residence there, which, I must confess, is not without some degree of interest, as it is a place of great natural beauty.

The island is situated in the western part of the Aegean Sea, about two hundred and fifty miles from the shore of Greece. It is a small island, of a moderate size, and surrounded by rocky shores. The climate is hot and dry, and the soil is fertile. The soil is the principal feature of the island, and the poet has been so enamoured of it, that he has made it the scene of many of his favourite walks.

The town of Mitylene is a small village, with a few hundred inhabitants. It is situated on the top of a hill, and is surrounded by a high wall, which gives it a certain air of security. The town is well supplied with water, and the inhabitants are well fed. The only drawback to the place is the heat, which is very great, especially in the summer months.

The poet's house is a beautiful and spacious mansion, which he has built for himself. It is situated in a garden, surrounded by a high wall, and is surrounded by a large lake. The lake is a favourite with the poet, and he has made many of his walks around it. The lake is a great object of beauty to the inhabitants of the village, and is a source of great pleasure to the poet.

I must say that the poet's residence at Mitylene was a most pleasant place to visit. He was always a man of great pleasure, and loved nothing so well as the simple pleasures of nature. He was a great lover of the sea, and the island of Mitylene is one of his favourite haunts. The poet was a great walker, and the island is a favourite with him. He would spend many hours walking on its shores, and exploring its hills and valleys.

I must say that I was most struck by the beauty of the island, and the beauty of the poet. He was a man of great imagination, and the island of Mitylene was one of his favourite scenes. I have no doubt that he will always be a favourite of the poet's, and that the island will always be a favourite of his imagination.

I hope that this account has been of some interest to your readers. I must say that I am most grateful to the poet for allowing me to write an account of his residence at Mitylene.

Yours sincerely,
Sir Walter Scott
37:
ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE, &c.

There is little information available on the exact location of the residence of Lord Byron, but he lived in the following places:

- Missolonghi, Greece 
- Missolonghi was a Greek town in the Peloponnese, in the Peloponnese region of Greece. It is situated near the foot of Mount Parnassus, and is the site of the ancient city of Elis. Byron visited the town in 1787, where he was entertained by the local population, and was deeply affected by the suffering of the Greeks during the Greek War of Independence.

- Missolonghi was also the site of Byron's birthplace, and he was born in a house in the town on April 22, 1788.

- In 1827, Byron was imprisoned in Missolonghi for 16 months, after being arrested and accused of inciting the Greek War of Independence.
38: "the world was all before him, where to choose his place of rest, and Providence his guide."
39: In sailing through the Greek Archipelago, on board His Majesty's vessels, in the year 1822, we put into the harbour of Mitylene, in the island of that name. The beauty of this place, and the certainty of supply of cattle and vegetables always to be had there, induce many British vessels to visit it—both men of war and merchantmen; and though it lies rather out of the track for ships bound to Smyrna, its bounties amply repay for the devotion of a voyage. We landed; as usual, at the bottom of the bay, and whilst the men were employed in watering, and the purser bargaining for cattle with the natives, the clergyman and I took a walk to the cave called Homer's School, and other places, where we had been before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain so named) we met with and engaged a young Greek as our guide, who told us he had come from Sicily with an English lord, who least the isolated sour days previous to our arrival in his felucca. He engaged me as a pilot, and would have taken me with him; but I did not choose to quit Mylylene, where I am likely to get married. He was odd, but a very good man. The cottage over the hill, facing the river, belongs to hm, and he has left an old mcn in charge of it: ho gave Dominick, the whle trader, six hundred zechines for it, (about £250 English currency,) and has resided there about fourteen months, though not constantly; for he sails in his felucca very oftent1e to the differont islands.
40: This account of our couriosity very much, and we lost no time in hastening to the house, where our countryman had retired. We were kindly received by an old man, who conducted us over the mansion. It consisted of four apartments on the ground floor—an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a sitting room, and a bedroom, with a spacious closet annexed. They were all simply decorated: plain green-stained walls, marble tablets on either side, a large myrtle in the centre, and a small fountain beneath, which could be played through the branches by moving a spring fixed in the side of a small bronze Venus in a leaning posture; a large couch or sofa completed the furniture. In the hall stood half a dozen English cane chairs, and an empty bookcase: there were no mirrors, or a single painting. The bedchamber had merely a largo mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed cotlons and a pillow—the common bed throughout Greece. In the sitting-room we observed a marble recess, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which were then in a large sailor's chest in the closet: it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. Ori the tablet os the recess lay Voltaire's, Shakspeare's, Boileau's, and Rausseau's works complete; Volney's Ruins of Empires; Zimmerman, in the German language; Klopstock's Messiah; Kotzebue's novels; Schiller's play of the Robbers; Milton's Paradise Lost, an Italian edition, printed at Parma in 1810; several small pamphlets from the Greek press at Constantinoplc, much torn, but no English book of any description. Most of those books were filled with marginal notes, written with a pencil, in Italian on and Latin. The Messiah was literally scribbled all over, and marked with slips of paper, on which also were remarks.
41: The old man said: "The lord had been reading these books the evening before he sailed, and forgot to place them with the others; but," said he, "they must lie until his return; for he is so particular, that were I to move one thing without orders, he would frown upon me for a week together; he is often good." I once did him a service; and I have the produce of this farm for the trouble of taking care of it, except twenty eight chickens which I pay to an aged Armenian who resides in a small cottage in the wood, and whom the lord brought from Adrianople; I don't know for what reason.
42: The appearance of the house externally was pleasing. The portico of the forum was fifly paces long and fourteen broad, and the fluted marble pillars with six black plints and fret-work cornices, (as it is now customary in Greek architecture,) were considered higher than the roos. The roof was surrounded by a light stone balustrade, covered by a fine Turkish carpet, beneath an awning of strong coarse linen. Most of the houses are furnished, upon them the Greeks pass their evenings in smoking, drinking light wines, such as "lachryma christi", eating fruit, and enjoying the evening breeze.
43: On the left hand as we endeared the house, a small streamlet glided away, grapes, oranges and limes were clustering together on its borders, and under the shade of two large myrtle bushes, a marble seat with an ornamental wooden back was placed, on which we were told, the lord passed many hours of his evenings and nights till twelve o'clock, reading, writing, and talking to himself. "I suppose," said the old man, "praying" for he was very devout, "and always attended church twice a week, besides Sundays."
44: The view from this seat called "a bird's-eye view." A line of rich vineyards led the eye to Mount Caffa, covered with olive and myrtle trees in bloom, and on the summit of which an ancient Greek temple appeared in majesty. A faint stream issuing from the ruins descended in brook cascades, untill the wall of the mountain's base. The sea, smooth as glass, and an horizon unshadowed by a single cloud, terminates in front; and a little to the left, through a vista of lofty heights and palm trees, several small islands were distinctly observed, studded with spots of emerald green. If seldom enjoyed a wife more than I did, but our inquiries were fruitless as to the name of the person who had resided in this romantic solitude: none knew his name but Dominick, his banker, who had gone to Candia. "tbe Armeniari," said the conductor, "could tell, but I am sure he will not,"—"And cannot you tell, old friend?" said I—"If I can," sald he, "I dare not." We had not time to visit the Armenian, but on our return to the town we learnt several particulars of the isolated lord. It is said that he had eight young girls when he was last on the island, and over-danced with them at the nuptial feast. He gave a cow to one man, horses to others, and cotton and silk to the girls who live weaving these articles. Also, he bought a new boat for a fisherman who had lost his own in a gale, and he often gave them pennies to the poor children. In short, he appeared to us, from all we collected, to have been a very eccentric and benevolent character. Ono circumstance we learnt, which our old friend at thc colledge thought proper not to disolose. He had a most beautiful daughter, with whom the ladies were often seen walking on the sea-bore, and he bought her a piano-forte, and taught her himself the use of it.
45: Such was the information with which we departed from the fair isle of Mitylene; our imaginations all on the rack, guessing who this rambler in Greece could be. He had money; it was evident: he had a disposition of philanthropy, and those eccentricities which mark peculiar genius. Arrived at Palermo, all our drafts were dispelled. Falling in love company Foster, the architect, a pupil of Wyatt's, who had been travelling in Egypt and Greece, "The individual," said he, "about whom you are so anxious, is Lord Byron; I made him in my travels on the island of Tenedos, and also visited him in Mytilene." We had never then heard of his lordship's fame, as we had been some years from home; but "Child Harold" being put into our hands, we recognised the recluse of Calaia in every page. Deeply did we regret not having been more curious in our researches at the cottage, but we confessed ourselfe with the idea of returning to Mitylene on some future day; but to me that day will never return. I make this statement, believing it not quite uninteresting, and in justice to his good reputation, which has been grossly slandered. He has been described as an unfeeling despot, acting against all that is good of association with human nature, or contributing in any way to soothe its  frays, or add its pleasures. The fact is directly the reverse, one may be partially gathered from these little anecdotes. All the finer feelings of the heart, elegantly depicted in his lordship's poems, seem to have their seat in his bosom. Tenderness, sympathy, and charity appear to guide all his actions: and his courting the repose of solitude is an additional reason for marking him as being on whose heart Religion has set her seal, and over whose head Benevolence hath thrown in its lot. No man can read the preceding passage "traits" without feeling proud of him as a countryman. With respect to his loves or pleasuros, I do not assume a right to give an opinion. Reports are ever to be received with caution, particularly where directed against man's moral integrity; and be who dare justly be in front of that awful tribunal where all must appear, alone may censure the errors of a fellow mortal. Lord Byron's character is worthy of his genius. To do good secretly, and shun the world's applause, is the surest testimony of a virtuous heart and self-approving conscience.
